Six Dimensions to
Patient-Centered Care

-Compassion, empathy and responsiveness to needs, values and expressed preferences
-Coordination and integration
-Information, communication and education
-Physical comfort
-Emotional support, relieving fear and anxiety
-Involvement of family and friends

Patient support
=
Better outcomes

The idea is that patients fare better when their families are more engaged in the care of their loved ones during the scary and stressful period when lives hang in the balance, said Dr. Giora Netzer, a critical care specialist at University of Maryland Medical Center.

Dr. Gloria Netzer, Critical Care Specialist, University of Maryland Medical Center

Case study

A Good Night's Rest

The caregiver’s job is important, but so is her own physical and emotional health. caregivers need to be sure to take time off – go home, get a good night’s sleep, and take care of their own life too.

Vance Esler, M.D Hematologist, Texas Oncology

Peer-to-peer support

Sometimes, I can’t talk to anyone about how I feel. I don’t want to burden them or take away the hope of my loved one. No one understands what this is really like unless they’ve been through it.
